FabricClient FabricClient Class

Definition

Namespace:
System.Fabric

System.Fabric.dll

Creates and manages Service Fabric services and other entities.

Edit

In this Article

Remarks

It is highly recommended that you share FabricClients as much as possible. This is because the FabricClient has multiple optimizations such as caching and batching that you would not be able to fully utilize otherwise.

Constructors

FabricClient() FabricClient()

Edit

Initializes a new instance of the FabricClient class.

public FabricClient()Public Sub New

Remarks

If the FabricClient is on the same cluster as the service, then use a Local FabricClient. Local FabricClient is a feature of Service Fabric that allows the FabricClient to connect to the local Gateway Service instead of choosing from a list. This way, your client can bypass an extra network hop. In case a service is resolving another service partition in the same cluster, then it is recommended that you use Local FabricClient, as it enables automatic load balancing and improves performance.

Initializes a new instance of the FabricClient class with the desired fabric client settings. If the FabricClient is on the same cluster as the service, then use a Local FabricClient. Local FabricClient is a feature of Service Fabric that allows the FabricClient to connect to the local Gateway Service instead of choosing from a list. This way, your client can bypass an extra network hop. In case a service is resolving another service partition in the same cluster, then it is recommended that you use Local FabricClient, as it enables automatic load balancing and improves performance.

FabricClient(SecurityCredentials, TimeSpan, String[]) FabricClient(SecurityCredentials, TimeSpan, String())

Edit

DEPRECATED. Initializes a new instance of the FabricClient class with given credentials, keepAliveInterval and Service Fabric Gateway addresses (hostEndpoints).

[Obsolete("Deprecated", true)]
public FabricClient(SecurityCredentials credential, TimeSpan keepAliveInterval, params string[] hostEndpoints)<Obsolete("Deprecated", True)>
Public Sub New(credential As SecurityCredentials, keepAliveInterval As TimeSpan, ParamArray hostEndpoints As String())
Parameters
credential
SecurityCredentials SecurityCredentials

Defines the security credentials.

keepAliveInterval
TimeSpan TimeSpan

Defines the periodic keep alive message interval.

hostEndpoints
String[] String()

Defines the set of Gateway addresses the FabricClient can use to connect to the cluster.

Attributes
ObsoleteAttribute

Remarks

If there are external devices in between the connection from the client to the cluster that require periodic messages to keep the connection alive, then make sure to use the KeepAlive feature of FabricClient. During the initialization of the FabricClient, users can specify a TimeSpan keepAliveInterval. If this argument is specified, then the FabricClient will periodically ping the Service Fabric Gateway Service it is currently communicating with, as long as there is a pending operation. An example of a scenario where this feature is useful is Windows Azure. If the FabricClient is outside of Windows Azure and the cluster is inside of Windows Azure, then all connections will go through the Azure Load Balancer (ALB). ALB terminates connections that are idle for more than 60 seconds. Hence, in these situations, FabricClient should be created with KeepAliveInterval set to <59 seconds (20 -30 is recommended).

Remarks

If there are external devices in between the connection from the client to the cluster that require periodic messages to keep the connection alive, then make sure to use the KeepAlive feature of FabricClient. During the initialization of the FabricClient, users can specify a TimeSpan keepAliveInterval. If this argument is specified, then the FabricClient will periodically ping the Service Fabric Gateway Service it is currently communicating with, as long as there is a pending operation. An example of a scenario where this feature is useful is Windows Azure. If the FabricClient is outside of Windows Azure and the cluster is inside of Windows Azure, then all connections will go through the Azure Load Balancer (ALB). ALB terminates connections that are idle for more than 60 seconds. Hence, in these situations, FabricClient should be created with KeepAliveInterval set to <59 seconds (20 -30 is recommended).

InfrastructureManager InfrastructureManager

Edit

Gets the FabricClient.InfrastructureServiceClient to perform operations related to the infrastructure on which the cluster is running.

This property supports the Service Fabric platform; it is not meant to be called directly from your code.

TestManager TestManager

Edit

Gets the FabricClient.TestManagementClient to perform complex actions that go through FaultAnalysisService. For example, StartPartitionDataLossAsync. This also supports APIs for validation (that do not go through FaultAnalysisService). For example, ValidateServiceAsync.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException ArgumentNullException

The specified fabric client settings cant be null.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

PartitionLocationCacheLimit must be positive.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

PartitionLocationCacheBucketCount must be greater or equal to zero.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

ServiceChangePollInterval must represent a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

ConnectionInitializationTimeout must represent a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

KeepAliveInterval must be zero or a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

ConnectionIdleTimeout must be zero or a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

HealthOperationTimeout must represent a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

HealthReportSendInterval must be zero or a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

HealthReportRetrySendInterval must represent a positive duration.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

PartitionLocationCacheBucketCount must be greater or equal to zero.

ArgumentException ArgumentException

AuthTokenBufferSize must be greater or equal to zero.
